name: Object Storage with Amazon S3
description: Key concepts, use cases, security, and storage classes for Amazon S3

cards.front: You're tasked with storing user-uploaded images that must be publicly accessible via URL and scaled to petabytes over time. Which AWS storage solution best meets this need?
cards.back: Amazon S3 is ideal for this use case. It's an object storage service with virtually unlimited scalability, supports direct web access via URL, and allows public access through bucket policies.
cards.example: A photo-sharing app uses Amazon S3 to store user photos with public URLs for display in mobile apps.
cards.subject: Object Storage with Amazon S3

cards.front: Your compliance team needs to retain customer records for 10 years, and retrieval is needed only once a year. Which S3 storage class should you use?
cards.back: Amazon S3 Glacier Deep Archive is designed for long-term storage with infrequent access and is the lowest-cost option for archival needs.
cards.example: A healthcare company archives patient records in S3 Glacier Deep Archive to meet HIPAA compliance.
cards.subject: Object Storage with Amazon S3

cards.front: You want to automate the movement of rarely accessed documents from S3 Standard to a lower-cost storage class. What S3 feature should you use?
cards.back: Use S3 Lifecycle Management to define transition rules that automatically move objects to more cost-effective storage classes over time.
cards.example: Logs stored in S3 are set to transition to S3 Glacier after 90 days using lifecycle policies.
cards.mnemonic: Lifecycle = Let It Flow Over Time
cards.subject: Object Storage with Amazon S3

cards.front: A developer accidentally overwrote an important image in an S3 bucket. What feature could have prevented data loss by preserving previous versions?
cards.back: S3 Versioning enables you to keep multiple versions of an object in the same bucket, allowing recovery from accidental overwrites or deletions.
cards.example: Versioning is enabled on an S3 bucket, allowing a developer to restore a prior version of employeephoto.jpg after it was accidentally replaced.
cards.subject: Object Storage with Amazon S3

cards.front: You're setting up cross-account access to allow another AWS account to upload objects to your S3 bucket. Which access control method should you use?
cards.back: Use an S3 Bucket Policy to grant cross-account permissions directly on the bucket, without needing IAM roles.
cards.example: An S3 bucket policy allows AWS Account B to write objects into a bucket owned by Account A.
cards.subject: Object Storage with Amazon S3
